Violation_Type: Failure to meet legal standards in risk assessment
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution risks due to ethnicity and past experiences in Sri Lanka, including detention and torture; Officer reviewed country conditions and personal history
Procedural_Issue: Alleged misapplication of legal standards and failure to consider relevant evidence
Evidence_Used: Past detention records, torture claims, country condition reports
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient objective evidence to support new risks upon return
Outcome: Application dismissed, no reviewable error found
Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question of law
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk to life under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Officer's decision was consistent with evidence and prior decisions; no reviewable error identified

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk upon return to Algeria due to sexual orientation and perceived Jewish identity; previous asylum claims denied
Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant seeking PRRA and H&C relief
Residency_Compliance: Subject to deportation; residency not established or maintained
Procedural_Issue: Lack of procedural fairness
Failure to provide oral hearing despite credibility concerns
Evidence_Used: Affidavits, personal testimony, documentary evidence related to sexual orientation and religious perception
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer required more corroborative evidence than reasonably necessary
Some evidence was ignored
Credibility_Assessment: Implicit adverse credibility findings made without oral hearing
Relief_Sought: Positive determination on PRRA and H&C applications
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination by different officers
Procedural fairness
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for PRRA/H&C decisions
Correctness for procedural fairness and legal questions
Decision_Rationale: Unreasonable demand for corroboration
Breach of procedural fairness
Inadequate consideration of evidence

Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA Officer's decision not to grant Pre-Removal Risk Assessment is reasonable
Evidence_Assessment: PRRA Officer reviewed evidence including medical reports; applicant lacked credibility
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate personalized risk
Legal_Rule: Standard of review is reasonableness simpliciter or patent unreasonableness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of credible evidence of personalized risk
Legal_Framework: Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA) process under IRPA
Legal_Provision: Sections of Immigration and Refugee Protection Act related to PRRA

Legal_Issue: Risk of torture or persecution upon deportation to India
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application for stay of removal
Evidence_Assessment: PRRA officer's findings supported by documentary evidence; Amnesty International reports submitted by applicant but not sufficient to overturn PRRA assessment
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to demonstrate a serious issue to be tried or irreparable harm
Credibility_Factor: PRRA officer found applicant's risk claims not credible; reliance on updated country conditions
Legal_Rule: Court must find a serious issue to be tried and irreparable harm for a stay; deference to PRRA officer's factual findings unless unsupported by evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged risk of torture and persecution in India due to political opinion or membership in particular social group
Outcome_on_Merits: No substantial risk of persecution or torture established
Key_Evidence_Considered: PRRA report, documentary country condition reports, Amnesty International reports
Legal_Framework: Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA), Section 115 of IRPA, Article 3 of CAT
Defendant_Response: Immigration authorities maintained that country conditions in India have improved and applicant's claim lacks credibility
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, Country condition reports, NGO reports
Outcome: Stay denied; removal order remains enforceable

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess Internal Flight Alternative
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96-98
Governing_Law: International Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution by LTTE and Sri Lankan authorities; Board found IFA in Colombo; applicant detained by police but not deemed persecuted; Board misapprehended applicant as not a 'young Tamil'
Claimant_Status: Tamil individual from Sri Lanka seeking refugee status
Procedural_Issue: Board erred in evidence interpretation; failed to correctly apply legal test for IFA; misapprehension of key factual category ('young Tamil')
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, reports on conditions in Colombo, detention records
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board overlooked or misinterpreted evidence regarding applicant’s identity as a 'young Tamil'
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims partially accepted, but IFA deemed available
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied based on existence of IFA in Colombo
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee, protection from removal to Sri Lanka
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim by a differently constituted Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities; serious possibility of persecution; reasonableness of internal flight alternative
Decision_Rationale: Board concluded no serious risk of persecution in Colombo and that relocation was reasonable, but made an error in fact-finding regarding applicant's profile as a 'young Tamil'
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CBSA officer's decision under subsection 72(1) of IRPA
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), subsection 72(1)
Evidence_Assessment: New evidence (affidavit, letter, documents) assessed as insufficient to establish Jewish identity or personalized risk
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to present compelling new evidence in PRRA
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's credibility previously rejected in 2002 asylum claim
Legal_Rule: PRRA assessments must consider new evidence not available during original claim; prior findings respected unless contradicted
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged anti-Semitic risks in Ukraine due to Jewish identity
Outcome_on_Merits: No personalized risk found; application dismissed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Affidavit, personal letter, supporting documents related to Jewish identity
Defendant_Response: CBSA officer concluded no new evidence undermined prior credibility finding
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Authority: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) officer, Federal Court

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether an oral hearing was required to assess credibility regarding sexual orientation
Review_Mechanism: Federal Court review of PRRA decision
Criminal_Activity: Drug trafficking resulting in loss of permanent resident status
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Serious criminality under IRPA due to drug trafficking conviction
Risk_Nexus: Claimed risk due to sexual orientation in country of origin
Outcome: Application dismissed; no oral hearing required
Basis_for_Decision: Decision based on sufficiency of evidence, not credibility
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: None found; no requirement for oral hearing where credibility is not central

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Mr. El Bousserghini and Ms. Kranfouli were physically present in Canada for over 1,095 days during the four-year period preceding their citizenship application
Procedural_Issue: Minister challenged the decision on grounds of insufficient evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Alleged by Minister, but not proven
Credibility_Assessment: Passive indicia accepted as sufficient by Citizenship Judge
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: No palpable error demonstrated by Minister; evidence sufficient to support residency claim

Application_Facts: PRRA officer excluded 20 documents deemed not 'new', despite letters from credible sources such as state officials providing significant corroboration of Mr. Elezi's claims.
Procedural_Issue: Exclusion of new evidence under subsection 113(a) without proper justification
Evidence_Used: 20 documents, including letters from credible sources like state officials
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider key corroborating evidence that was reasonably available or arose after the Board's rejection
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by the Board; PRRA application denied
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision quashed; matter remitted for a new hearing with a different officer
Relief_Sought: Acceptance of refugee claim and protection
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and a new PRRA assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether the PRRA officer correctly applied subsection 113(a) of the IRPA regarding new evidence
Decision_Rationale: The PRRA officer erred in excluding critical evidence that could significantly support the claimant's case, warranting a new hearing

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section C.08.002 of the Food and Drug Regulations
Application_Facts: Applicant filed a New Drug Submission (NDS) relying on literature references instead of required clinical trial data.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application challenging administrative decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clinical trial data in NDS submission
Decision_Outcome: Health Canada's rejection of NDS upheld
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Health Canada's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Section C.08.002 requires clinical trial data; applicant failed to provide it; reliance on literature insufficient; Health Canada acted within regulatory authority.

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 493 days during the relevant four-year period, resulting in 636 days of physical presence in Canada; strong ties to Canada were not adequately considered
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge applied unclear tests and omitted key factors; insufficient reasoning
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, evidence of ties to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider pre-application residency and strong connections to Canada
Decision_Outcome: Original application denied by Citizenship Judge
Relief_Sought: Overturn of denial and grant of citizenship
Remedy_Sought: New hearing before a different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of physical presence required within four years prior to application
Decision_Rationale: Judge made errors in law and failed to provide adequate reasons; strong ties to Canada were not properly assessed
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (via Citizenship Judge), Federal Court on appeal

Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 72(1)(e)(i) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Criminality leading to inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Criminal inadmissibility due to family member's conviction
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's son was under 22 at time of application, making him a dependent child
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Not met due to family member inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether s. 42 applies to permanent residency requirements
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reapplication once son is no longer a dependent
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Dependent child's criminal inadmissibility affects principal applicant

Application_Facts: Applicants challenged Citizenship Officer's refusal of citizenship application for adopted daughter
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of breach of procedural fairness
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for evidence assessment
Correctness standard for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Decision based on total evidence; no key contradictory evidence ignored; third-party assistance did not affect decision-making

Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in testimony, lack of media reports, medical records, lawyer's letter

Crimes.Threat_Source: Government official after assault and threats

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to ongoing threats
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, due to resistance of advances

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim due to property damage and threats
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Media coverage assumption, medical omissions, lawyer's letter

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board failed to consider reasonable explanations

Application_Facts: Dr. El Ocla was absent from Canada due to professional obligations but maintained strong ties to Canada, including centralized mode of living in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Physical presence not met (1095 days in 4 years), but qualitative residency potentially satisfied
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to consider qualitative residency test under s 5(1)(c)
Evidence_Used: Evidence of professional absences, maintained ties to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not assess evidence relevant to qualitative residency
Decision_Outcome: Original application rejected based solely on physical presence
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by another citizenship judge applying both physical and qualitative tests
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test under Citizenship Act; failure to apply qualitative residency test under s 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: The citizenship judge erred by not considering the qualitative residency test despite evidence of centralized life in Canada

Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 3(c), 16, 24, 71, 75, and 91 of Samson Election Law
Application_Facts: The applicant was disqualified for not meeting residency requirements after complaints were filed. The law does not explicitly outline a pre-election disqualification process, but Section 16 implies broad authority for the Electoral Supervisor.
Procedural_Issue: Lack of explicit pre-election disqualification process in the law
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether the Electoral Supervisor exceeded jurisdiction by disqualifying the applicant after the nomination meeting
Decision_Outcome: Electoral Supervisor did not exceed jurisdiction; application for judicial review dismissed
Outcome: Applicant's name remained off the candidate list
Decision_Rationale: Section 16 implies broad authority for the Electoral Supervisor over elections

Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate Grounds Application Refusal
Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate unusual or disproportionate hardship
Application_Facts: Mr. Kawtharani’s refugee claim was denied; he remained in Canada and applied for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on family ties, establishment in Canada, and risk upon return to Lebanon.
Residency_Compliance: Remained in Canada after refugee claim denial
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of inadequate reasons and improper assessment of hardship and risk by H&C officer
Evidence_Used: Assessment of establishment in Canada, family ties, and ability to reintegrate into Lebanon
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant did not provide sufficient evidence of unusual or disproportionate hardship
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of H&C refusal and grant of permanent residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in assessing H&C applications under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The H&C officer adequately considered relevant factors including hardship, risk, establishment, and reintegration prospects; no procedural fairness breach occurred
Authority_Responsible: H&C Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's criminal history and alleged gang leadership raising public safety concerns in Canada versus risk of torture/persecution in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to deportation due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly reassess risks as per prior court order
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reliance on outdated evidence; ignored credible NGO and SLMM reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent weighing of evidence and sources
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed and remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Prevention of deportation due to risk of torture
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of risk and balancing exercise
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Flawed evidence treatment and improper balancing of danger to public vs. risk upon return

Crimes.Violation_Type: Deportation based on serious criminality despite refugee status
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant’s history of serious criminality and gang involvement while being a Convention refugee
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to deportation due to seriousness of criminal acts
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review following prior court-ordered reassessment
Evidence_Used: Corroborative evidence of targeting by authorities or LTTE
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Ignored relevant NGO reports and failed to address corroboration
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed and remanded for new assessment
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Halt deportation due to risk of cruel treatment
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: New risk assessment and balancing under s. 97 and s. 115(2)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to reasonably assess risk of torture and balance against public danger

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to consider updated and credible evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Relevant reports were available but dismissed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable assessment of risk and evidence
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged gang leadership and organized criminal involvement
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: History of serious criminality and gang association
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Danger to the public and organized criminality
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Risk of targeting by Sri Lankan authorities or LTTE upon return
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reassessment
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Flawed evaluation of evidence regarding risk in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Dismissal of corroborative and credible evidence without justification

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed domestic violence as persecution in Georgia; inconsistencies in testimony post-2005 affected credibility
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable - claimant was seeking status
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in applicant's testimony affecting credibility
Procedural_Issue: RAD's standard of review on RPD's credibility findings
Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of RAD and Federal Court in refugee appeals
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, documentation related to domestic violence claim
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in testimony post-2005
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant not credible post-2005; RAD upheld finding under reasonableness standard while conducting independent assessment
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected due to credibility issues
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of RAD's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: No reviewable error by RAD; RAD properly applied deference where RPD had advantage and conducted independent assessment
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Federal Court

Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Mr. Kina's testimony contained inconsistencies between his PIF, amended PIF, and hearing testimony. Ms. Kinova had no negative credibility finding but insufficient evidence to rebut the presumption of state protection. The Board's analysis focused on systemic efforts rather than operational adequacy of state protection.
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in Mr. Kina's statements across documents and testimony
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate credibility and state protection analysis by the Board
Evidence_Used: Personal Information Form (PIF), amended PIF, hearing testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence from Ms. Kinova to rebut presumption of state protection
Lack of focus on operational adequacy of state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Significant portions of Mr. Kina's testimony found non-credible
No negative credibility finding for Ms. Kinova
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a differently constituted Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Test for state protection: adequacy, not perfect effectiveness
Claimant must rebut presumption of state protection with clear and convincing evidence
Decision_Rationale: Board's conclusions on credibility, state protection, and nexus to a Convention ground were unreasonable due to inadequate analysis

Application_Facts: Mr. Huang, with limited education, joined an underground church after experiencing depression. He fled China following a raid on the church and claimed refugee status in Canada based on religious persecution.
Procedural_Issue: The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) decision was reviewed for reasonableness. The Federal Court found issues with the RPD's assessment process and credibility analysis.
Evidence_Used: Mr. Huang's testimony regarding his religious practice, knowledge of Christianity, and circumstances of fleeing China.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: The RPD identified insufficient knowledge of Christianity as a basis for rejecting credibility, but the court found the errors minor relative to his overall understanding.
Credibility_Assessment: The RPD found Mr. Huang not credible due to perceived lack of Christian knowledge. The Federal Court determined this assessment unreasonable given his background and level of education.
Decision_Outcome: The RPD initially rejected Mr. Huang’s refugee claim. The Federal Court vacated the decision.
Outcome: The RPD's decision was set aside, and the case was remanded to a different panel for reassessment.
Relief_Sought: Mr. Huang sought recognition as a Convention refugee based on a well-founded fear of persecution for religious beliefs.
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review to overturn the RPD's negative credibility finding and have the claim reassessed.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard applied to assess the RPD’s decision under administrative law principles.
Decision_Rationale: The RPD's credibility determination was unreasonable because it failed to account for Mr. Huang’s limited education and context-specific understanding of Christianity. Minor inaccuracies do not undermine overall credibility.
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Immigration and Refugee Board; subject to judicial review by the Federal Court.

Violation_Type: Failure to prove persecution or lack of state protection
Application_Facts: Applicants are Roma from Hungary who faced discrimination and claimed fear of persecution; they sought refugee protection in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Claimants fled Hungary and applied for refugee status in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Challenge to RPD decision in court
Evidence_Used: Incident reports, police responses, evidence of state efforts to protect Roma in Hungary
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence for police to take further action; applicants did not exhaust all reasonable steps to access state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' claims of persecution were not sufficiently supported by evidence
Outcome: Court dismissed the application and upheld RPD's decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review overturning RPD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard; burden of proof on applicants to demonstrate persecution or lack of state protection under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: RPD's conclusion was reasonable as Hungary provided adequate state protection and applicants failed to prove inability to access such protection

Violation_Type: Failure to prove inability to return to country of former habitual residence
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) - sections relating to refugee protection and returnability
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk upon return to India; argued NORI stamp does not guarantee re-entry without visa; no evidence presented on visa denials
Residency_Compliance: Alleged non-compliance with residency requirements or re-entry conditions
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of RAD's dismissal of RPD decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence regarding visa denial history or barriers to re-entry
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to establish credibility on inability to return
Decision_Outcome: RAD accepted RPD finding; appeal dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of RAD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for RAD decisions; burden on applicant to demonstrate inability to return
Decision_Rationale: No error by RAD in accepting RPD's conclusion due to lack of contrary evidence
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Federal Court (judicial review)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Protect (state's responsibility, not a direct crime by the applicants)
Application_Facts: extortion, sexual assault, physical assault, kidnapping by La Familia cartel
Evidentiary_Deficiency: lack of nexus to Convention grounds
Remedy_Sought: judicial review
Legal_Standard_Applied: well-founded fear of persecution
Decision_Rationale: risks were generalized, no nexus to Convention ground

Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution in Turkey based on ethnicity, religion, and political opinion
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to meaningfully consider psychological report in credibility assessment
Evidence_Used: Dr. Devins' psychological report diagnosing chronic posttraumatic stress disorder
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of discussion on relevance of PTSD diagnosis to credibility
Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned applicant's credibility but did not adequately address impact of mental health condition
Decision_Outcome: Board dismissed claim primarily due to credibility concerns
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a different panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Patent unreasonableness standard for credibility findings
Decision_Rationale: Board's failure to analyze medical evidence affecting credibility was clearly unreasonable

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Willoughby was absent for 745 days during the four-year period before application and maintained a home in Australia
Residency_Compliance: Did not meet statutory three-year physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to adequately analyze absences and connection to Canada under Koo factors
Evidence_Used: Duration of absences, maintenance of residence in Australia
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of Willoughby's ties to Canada despite dual residences
Relief_Sought: Minister sought overturning of citizenship judge’s approval
Remedy_Sought: Appeal of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo factors for qualitative assessment of residency
Decision_Rationale: Extensive absences and dual residences undermined sufficient connection to Canada; inadequate application of Koo factors by judge

Application_Facts: Ms. Williams fears her brother due to his violence and mental instability; there was credible evidence of police intervention and Jeremy's institutionalization; no sexual abuse involved
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the RPD's decision
Evidence_Used: Evidence of police intervention, Jeremy's institutionalization, lack of state protection in prior domestic abuse cases (distinguished)
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found Ms. Williams' fear credible but determined state protection was effective
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of RPD's decision on state protection
Decision_Rationale: State protection in St. Vincent and the Grenadines is effective and not illusory; presumption of state protection in democratic countries stands as evidence did not rebut it
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board - Refugee Protection Division (IRB-RPD)

Violation_Type: Judicial review of PRRA decision post-removal
Application_Facts: Applicant is a Tamil from Sri Lanka who alleged risk of persecution; PRRA application was denied; applicant was removed from Canada despite seeking judicial review.
Procedural_Issue: Filing of judicial review after removal; mootness of application
Jurisdictional_Issue: Court may lack authority to order return or reassessment after removal
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment or relief from removal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Mootness doctrine; discretion to hear in cases of legal uncertainty and adversarial context
Decision_Rationale: Application largely moot post-removal, but court exercised discretion to hear due to legal uncertainty and adversarial process

Application_Facts: Two sisters applied to visit their brother in Canada; applications refused based on perceived weak ties to Iran
Residency_Compliance: Applicants claimed strong family ties in Iran; officer incorrectly assessed ties as limited
Procedural_Issue: Visa officer failed to meaningfully analyze listed factors
Consideration of irrelevant facts (e.g., mismatched bank turnovers)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of evidence
Lack of explanation for credibility or reliability assessments
Credibility_Assessment: No explicit finding, but implicit negative assessment due to 'mismatched' bank turnovers
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa refusal decisions
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of applications by a new visa officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Decisions lacked sufficient reasoning, failed to properly consider relevant factors, and included irrelevant considerations
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer at Canadian visa office

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of negative credibility finding based on document misrepresentation
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding deemed patently unreasonable
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to gender-based violence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Cultural norms affecting disclosure of sexual violence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Impact of trauma and cultural sensitivity on testimony
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted for redetermination by new panel

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Use of false documents as basis for negative credibility finding
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding deemed patently unreasonable
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to gender-based violence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Trauma and psychological state affecting consistency
Crimes.Application_Error: Focus on minor or explainable inconsistencies
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted for redetermination by new panel

Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision to reject the applicant's refugee claim based on reasonable grounds?
Governing_Law: subsection 18.1(4) of the Federal Court Act
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no certification questions raised
Credibility_Assessment: The Board questioned inconsistencies in the applicant's testimony, lack of supporting documentation, and contradictions regarding his US asylum claim
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility doubts due to inconsistent statements and lack of evidence

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant lived in Canada since age three, has Canadian spouse and child, no recent criminal activity
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Non-status individual with pending humanitarian and compassionate application

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Adult offender with prior criminal record
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Rehabilitation, family ties in Canada, no imminent danger to public

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Adult offender with history of reformation
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Long-term residence in Canada since childhood, marriage to Canadian citizen, parental responsibilities

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant has Canadian-born child, no further charges since past convictions, pending humanitarian application

Legal_Issue: Whether applicants can prove irreparable harm to justify a stay of removal
Evidence_Assessment: Business loss and potential U.S. detention were unsubstantiated; no evidence of life-threatening harm upon return
Decision_Outcome: Motion denied, removal order to proceed
Burden_of_Proof: Applicants failed to meet burden of proving irreparable harm
Credibility_Factor: Claims discredited; no credible risk found by Refugee Division and PRRA officer
Legal_Rule: Irreparable harm must be proven, not speculative, and cannot rely solely on discredited claims
Standard_of_Review: Assessment based on prior tribunal decisions and Federal Court review
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk in returning to Turkey, potential harm in the U.S.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Findings of Refugee Division and PRRA officer, lack of evidence on business loss and detention risk
Legal_Framework: Immigration and refugee protection legislation, stay of removal procedures
Authority: Federal Court, Refugee Division, PRRA officer

Violation_Type: Participation in atrocities while seeking refugee status
Governing_Law: UN Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant admitted participation in CDR atrocities; claimed to be spying for an opposition group
Misrepresentation_Element: Claimed espionage as justification for involvement
Procedural_Issue: Exclusion from refugee protection based on credible evidence of involvement
Credibility_Assessment: Involvement found to be knowing and violent; espionage claim not accepted
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious reasons for considering
Standard_of_Review: On the facts and law, Refugee Board decision upheld on judicial review
Decision_Rationale: Voluntary, active, and violent participation in atrocities disqualifies under Article 1F(a)

Sub_Crime_Type: Perpetration of atrocities as part of CDR
Credibility_Assessment: Espionage defense rejected due to nature and extent of involvement

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1F(a) of the UN Refugee Convention
Legal_Framework: Customary international law on crimes against humanity
Jurisdiction: National asylum jurisdiction applying international law
Risk_Factor: Perpetrator of past human rights abuses
Credibility: Applicant's account assessed and partially rejected
Risk_Nature: Risk of harm to others due to prior conduct

Crime_Name: Misuse of public funds and serious breaches in management
Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; Commissioner ordered to disclose information
Decision_Outcome: Execution of order suspended pending further appeal
Government_Body_or_Authority: Office of the Public Sector Integrity Commissioner
Individual_Status_or_Claim: Applicant accused based on investigation findings
State_Protection_Adequacy: Found inadequate due to lack of transparency and potential bias

Application_Facts: Laquerre and his companies evaded taxes by mingling personal and corporate assets, using trusts to avoid liabilities. Evidence shows deliberate schemes to defraud creditors and evade taxes, violating public order principles.
Procedural_Issue: Motion for charging order absolute before Tax Court resolves appeals on reassessments
Evidence_Used: Audits, affidavits, evidence of asset mingling, use of trusts, and fraudulent schemes
Outcome: Corporate veil lifted; absolute charge granted against immovables
Remedy_Sought: Enforcement of tax debt payment through charging immovables
Legal_Standard_Applied: Rule 459(1) Federal Courts Rules; Article 317 C.C.Q.
Decision_Rationale: Non-payment of tax debts contravenes public order; fraudulent use of corporate structures justifies lifting the corporate veil.

Dispute_Type: Tax debt enforcement vs. pending appeals
Legal_Issue: Can the court issue a charging order absolute when tax debts are disputed and appeals are pending?
Governing_Law: Rule 459 of the Federal Courts Rules, Article 317 of the Civil Code of Quebec
Procedural_Stage: Motion for absolute charging order following interim order
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence shows Laquerre and his companies owe significant tax debts and engaged in asset mingling and tax evasion schemes.
Burden_of_Proof: On judgment creditor to show grounds for charging order; met based on evidence of fraud and non-payment
Credibility_Factor: Evidence of deliberate tax evasion and asset concealment
Legal_Rule: Rule 459 allows making an interim charge absolute; non-payment may contravene public order under Article 317 C.C.Q.
Grounds_for_Claim: Unpaid tax debts, use of corporate structures to evade liabilities
Outcome_on_Merits: Court ruled in favor of judgment creditor
Key_Evidence_Considered: Audits, affidavits, financial records showing asset commingling
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Rules, Civil Code of Quebec
Defendant_Response: Respondents opposed, citing legitimate business activities and pending appeals
Outcome: Charging order absolute issued; properties charged to secure tax debt payment

Dispute_Type: Enforcement of tax debt against corporate-owned immovables despite pending appeals
Legal_Issue: Can a charging order absolute be issued against immovables owned by companies linked to the debtor despite pending tax appeals?
Governing_Law: Rule 459(1) Federal Courts Rules, Article 317 C.C.Q.
Procedural_Stage: Post-interim charging order; motion for absolute order
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence shows asset mingling, use of corporate entities to evade tax obligations, and violation of public order
Burden_of_Proof: Met by judgment creditor through evidence of fraudulent structuring
Credibility_Factor: Consistent pattern of evading tax liabilities using corporate vehicles
Legal_Rule: Article 317 C.C.Q. allows disregard of legal personality to prevent fraud; Rule 459 governs charging orders
Grounds_for_Claim: Use of corporate structures to conceal assets and evade tax payments
Key_Evidence_Considered: Financial records, ownership structures, audit findings
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Rules, Civil Code of Quebec
Defendant_Response: Opposition based on legitimacy of business structures and ongoing appeals
Remedy_Requested: Charging order absolute on six immovables
Outcome: Order granted; creditor allowed to enforce collection

Dispute_Type: Lifting corporate veil to enforce tax debt
Legal_Issue: Can the corporate veil be lifted to impose a charging order on company-owned immovables linked to Mario Laquerre?
Governing_Law: Article 317 C.C.Q., Rule 459 Federal Courts Rules
Procedural_Stage: Motion for absolute charging order after interim order
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence of mingling assets, tax evasion, and structuring to avoid liabilities
Decision_Outcome: Corporate veil lifted; charging order absolute granted
Burden_of_Proof: Satisfied by judgment creditor with audit and affidavit evidence
Credibility_Factor: Pattern of misuse of corporate forms for personal benefit and liability avoidance
Legal_Rule: Article 317 C.C.Q. permits disregarding legal personality to prevent fraud
Grounds_for_Claim: Systematic abuse of corporate entities to evade tax obligations
Key_Evidence_Considered: Audit results, ownership links, financial intermingling
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Rules, Civil Code of Quebec
Defendant_Response: Denial of wrongdoing, assertion of legitimate business operations
Remedy_Requested: Lifting of corporate veil and absolute charging order
Outcome: Veil lifted; charging order granted; costs awarded to creditor

Crime_Name: Trademark Infringement and Breach of Contract
Dispute_Type: Termination of franchise agreement and continued use of trademarks
Legal_Issue: Whether plaintiffs can obtain an interlocutory injunction for trademark infringement and false representation
Evidence_Assessment: Huron Shores ceased paying fees; dispute over termination notice and compliance
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs must show serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience
Credibility_Factor: Both parties presented credible arguments on the validity of termination and rights to use trademarks
Legal_Rule: Interlocutory injunction requires: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience favoring applicant
Grounds_for_Claim: Trademark infringement post-termination, breach of contract, false representation
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided; case remains open for full trial
Key_Evidence_Considered: Franchise agreement terms, payment history, notice of termination, use of trademarks
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law, common law principles of contract and injunctions
Defendant_Response: Claimed breach of contract by plaintiff and sought specific performance
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (contract), financial records, legal notices
Remedy_Requested: Interlocutory injunction to stop trademark use
Outcome: Injunction denied; status quo maintained with Huron Shores depositing 1.5% of gross income or $3,000 into trust account
Legal_Provision: Registered trademark protections, contractual termination clauses
Authority: Court applying equitable doctrines including 'clean hands'

National_Security_Danger: Reasonable grounds to believe Mr. Charkaoui posed a danger to national security
Threat_Assessment: Mr. Charkaoui assessed as no longer a danger due to reduced risk factors
Admission_or_Involvement: No admission; allegations based on intelligence and unproven claims
Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliance on secret or untested intelligence; polygraph results dismissed
Evidence_Type: Testimony, community support, behavioral patterns, polygraph results
Credibility_Assessment: Individual's testimony and community support considered credible
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 83(3)
Dispute_Type: Judicial review of administrative detention for national security reasons
Consequences_of_Action: Strict monitoring conditions imposed: curfews, restricted communication, electronic surveillance

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Assessment of flight risk and alternatives to detention
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of flight due to wealth and history
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to adequately assess alternatives to detention
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board
Crimes.Application_Error: Insufficient analysis of proposed GPS monitoring and private security surveillance
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Likelihood of appearing at admissibility hearing
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Release unless unlikely to appear (Section 58 IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of leaving Kazakhstan and financial resources
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, remitted for new detention review

Crimes.Violation_Type: Flight risk and failure to comply with immigration conditions
Crimes.Application_Facts: Wealth, ties to Kazakhstan, past departure from country
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national subject to immigration detention
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to risk of non-appearance
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged false statements related to criminal background
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Inadequate consideration of alternatives to detention
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Immigration Division under IRPA
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of thorough evaluation of proposed release conditions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubted likelihood of compliance with reporting obligations
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Unlikely to appear or danger to public
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Errors in assessing evidence and alternatives

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration detention based on alleged organized crime involvement
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to properly consider alternatives to detention
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Evidence considered but alternatives dismissed without full analysis
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Flight risk linked to organized crime connections
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Flight risk due to wealth and international ties
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Inadequate assessment of proposed monitoring measures

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Detention over financial crimes and flight risk
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of continued detention under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Weighing of flight risk versus proposed release conditions
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On Minister to justify continued detention
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Prior flight from justice and financial capacity
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 58 requires release unless unlikely to appear
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged money laundering and Interpol Red Notice
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Proposed GPS monitoring and private surveillance as alternatives
Crimes.Outcome: Remanded for new detention review within seven days

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD correctly determined it lacked jurisdiction under IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA sections 64(2), 196, and former Immigration Act section 49(1)(b)
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed; matter remitted to a different IAD panel
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 64(2), 196 IRPA; former Immigration Act s. 49(1)(b)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Automatic stay under former Immigration Act
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of automatic stay under former legislation
Crimes.Application_Error: IAD incorrectly applied section 196 by not recognizing automatic stay
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Interpretation of transitional provisions in IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Sentence imposed vs. time served for appeal eligibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD erred in dismissing appeal for lack of jurisdiction

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with temporary resident status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA section 196 in relation to appeal rights
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant sentenced to four years for drug trafficking, appeal pending when IRPA came into force
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliance due to criminal conviction and deportation order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Transitional application of IRPA appeal restrictions
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether IAD had jurisdiction under section 196
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal sentence and status under former Act
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD erred in dismissing appeal; jurisdiction retained due to automatic stay
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; remitted to IAD
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-adjudication by a different IAD panel
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of section 196 and transitional provisions
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Automatic stay under former Act preserved appeal rights

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of drugs for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Appeal jurisdiction under new immigration legislation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Application of IRPA section 196 to remove IAD jurisdiction
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction and sentence for drug possession with intent
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Adjudicator erred; IAD retains jurisdiction due to automatic stay
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show entitlement to appeal under transitional rules
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 196 does not apply if automatic stay existed under former Act
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Improper denial of appeal rights under IRPA transition
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Appeal should be heard by IAD under old rules
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Four-year sentence and pending appeal at time of IRPA enactment
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued automatic stay preserved appeal rights
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA section 196, former Immigration Act provisions

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk in Jamaica due to being openly lesbian
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of PRRA decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient corroborative evidence of sexual orientation
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Protection from deportation based on sexual orientation
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement for hearing under IRPA when serious credibility issue exists
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision based on insufficient evidence, not credibility; no hearing required

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Alleged breach in not holding oral hearing
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Claimed risk due to sexual orientation upon return to Jamaica
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Insufficient evidence of sexual orientation; decision not based on credibility
